innate_features.formula: Innate immunity is non-specific, present from birth, and provides immediate defence without prior exposure
innate_features.correct: Innate responses are rapid, don't require previous antigen exposure, and don't improve with repeated infections

wrong.answer: Innate immunity develops after pathogen exposure
wrong.fix: Innate immunity is present from birth; adaptive immunity develops after exposure
wrong.action: Innate = born with; Adaptive = develops after exposure

wrong.answer: Innate immunity is specific to each pathogen
wrong.error: Applying adaptive immunity characteristics to innate
wrong.fix: Innate immunity recognises general pathogen features (PAMPs), not specific antigens
wrong.action: Innate = pattern recognition; Adaptive = antigen-specific

wrong.answer: Innate immunity improves with each infection
wrong.fix: Innate immunity responds the same each time; only adaptive immunity has memory
wrong.action: Innate = same response; Adaptive = memory and improved response

persistent.gap: Confusion between innate and adaptive immunity characteristics
persistent.action: Compare: Innate (immediate, non-specific, no memory) vs Adaptive (delayed, specific, memory)

phagocytosis.formula: Phagocytosis involves engulfment of pathogens into a phagosome, fusion with lysosomes, and digestion
phagocytosis.correct: Phagocytes recognise pathogens via pattern recognition receptors, engulf them, and destroy them with lysosomal enzymes and reactive oxygen

wrong.answer: Phagocytosis kills pathogens before engulfment
wrong.fix: Pathogens are engulfed first, then killed inside the phagolysosome
wrong.action: Sequence: recognition → engulfment → phagosome → lysosome fusion → killing

wrong.answer: Phagosomes directly digest pathogens
wrong.fix: Phagosomes must fuse with lysosomes to form phagolysosomes for digestion
wrong.action: Phagosome + Lysosome = Phagolysosome (with digestive enzymes)

wrong.answer: All cells can perform phagocytosis
wrong.fix: Professional phagocytes include neutrophils, macrophages, and dendritic cells
wrong.action: Professional phagocytes: neutrophils, macrophages, dendritic cells

persistent.action: Trace: pathogen recognition → engulfment → phagosome → lysosome fusion → killing → antigen presentation

inflammation.formula: Inflammation involves vasodilation, increased permeability, and leukocyte recruitment to infection sites
inflammation.correct: Cardinal signs are redness (rubor), heat (calor), swelling (tumor), pain (dolor), and loss of function

wrong.answer: Inflammation is always harmful
wrong.error: Not recognising protective role of inflammation
wrong.fix: Inflammation is a protective response that recruits immune cells and promotes healing
wrong.action: Acute inflammation = protective; Chronic inflammation = potentially harmful

wrong.answer: Inflammation decreases blood flow
wrong.fix: Inflammation increases blood flow (vasodilation), bringing immune cells to the site
wrong.action: Vasodilation = more blood = redness, heat, swelling

wrong.answer: Inflammation prevents immune cells from entering tissues
wrong.error: Reversing the purpose of increased permeability
wrong.fix: Increased vascular permeability allows immune cells and proteins to enter tissues
wrong.action: Leaky vessels = immune cells exit blood → enter tissue

persistent.gap: Misunderstanding of inflammation purpose and mechanism
persistent.action: Remember: vasodilation + permeability = recruit immune cells + deliver proteins = fight infection

complement_system.formula: The complement system is a cascade of proteins that opsonise pathogens, recruit immune cells, and form membrane attack complexes
complement_system.correct: Complement can be activated by three pathways: classical (antibody), alternative (pathogen surface), and lectin (mannose)

wrong.answer: Complement only works with antibodies
wrong.fix: Alternative and lectin pathways can activate complement without antibodies
wrong.action: Classical = antibodies; Alternative = pathogen surfaces; Lectin = mannose

wrong.answer: Complement proteins are produced by pathogens
wrong.fix: Complement proteins are made by the liver and circulate in blood plasma
wrong.action: Complement = host proteins; PAMPs = pathogen molecules

wrong.answer: Complement only kills pathogens directly
wrong.fix: Complement also opsonises (marks) pathogens and promotes inflammation
wrong.action: Complement functions: opsonisation, inflammation, membrane attack (lysis)

persistent.gap: Limited understanding of complement activation and functions
persistent.action: Three outcomes: opsonisation (C3b), inflammation (C3a, C5a), lysis (MAC)

cytokines.formula: Cytokines are signalling molecules that coordinate immune responses between cells
cytokines.correct: Different cytokines have different effects: interleukins communicate between leukocytes; interferons inhibit viral replication

wrong.answer: Cytokines directly kill pathogens
wrong.fix: Cytokines are messengers that activate other cells; they don't kill directly
wrong.action: Cytokines = signals/messages; Immune cells = killers

wrong.answer: All cytokines have the same function
wrong.fix: Different cytokines have specific roles: some promote inflammation, some inhibit it
wrong.action: Pro-inflammatory (IL-1, TNF) vs Anti-inflammatory (IL-10) cytokines

wrong.answer: Cytokines only act on nearby cells
wrong.fix: Cytokines can act locally (paracrine) or systemically (endocrine) throughout the body
wrong.action: Cytokines: autocrine (self), paracrine (nearby), endocrine (systemic)

persistent.gap: Incomplete understanding of cytokine diversity and function
persistent.action: Key cytokines: IL-1/TNF (fever, inflammation), IFN (antiviral), IL-10 (suppressive)

interferons.formula: Interferons are cytokines that interfere with viral replication and activate immune cells
interferons.correct: Type I interferons (α, β) induce antiviral states in cells; Type II interferon (γ) activates macrophages

wrong.answer: Interferons kill viruses directly
wrong.fix: Interferons signal cells to produce antiviral proteins; they don't kill viruses directly
wrong.action: Interferons induce antiviral state → cells resistant to infection

wrong.answer: Interferons are only produced by infected cells
wrong.fix: Many cells produce interferons, including infected cells and activated immune cells
wrong.action: Infected cells → Type I IFN; Activated T/NK cells → Type II IFN

wrong.answer: Interferons only work on the cell that produces them
wrong.fix: Interferons protect neighbouring cells by inducing antiviral defences before infection
wrong.action: Infected cell → IFN → neighbouring cells → antiviral state

persistent.gap: Confusion about interferon mechanism and types
persistent.action: Type I (α/β): antiviral state in all cells; Type II (γ): macrophage activation

fever.formula: Fever is a systemic response where pyrogens raise the hypothalamic temperature set point
fever.correct: Elevated temperature enhances immune function, inhibits pathogen growth, and increases metabolic rate

wrong.answer: Fever is always harmful and should be suppressed
wrong.fix: Moderate fever enhances immune responses; only very high fevers are dangerous
wrong.action: Moderate fever = beneficial; Very high fever (>40°C) = dangerous

wrong.answer: Fever is caused by pathogens directly raising temperature
wrong.fix: Pyrogens signal the hypothalamus to raise the temperature set point
wrong.action: Pyrogens → hypothalamus → new set point → body generates heat

wrong.answer: Fever doesn't affect pathogen survival
wrong.fix: Many pathogens are temperature-sensitive and grow poorly at elevated temperatures
wrong.action: Higher temperature = slower pathogen replication

persistent.gap: Incomplete understanding of fever mechanism and benefits
persistent.action: Fever benefits: enhanced immunity, reduced pathogen growth, faster healing

pattern_recognition.formula: Pattern recognition receptors (PRRs) detect conserved pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs)
pattern_recognition.correct: Toll-like receptors (TLRs) recognise bacterial components like LPS; other PRRs detect viral RNA and fungal cell walls

wrong.answer: PRRs recognise specific antigens like antibodies do
wrong.fix: PRRs recognise general pathogen patterns (PAMPs); antibodies recognise specific epitopes
wrong.action: PRRs = pattern recognition; Antibodies = specific antigen recognition

wrong.answer: Each pathogen has a unique PAMP
wrong.fix: PAMPs are shared by many pathogens (e.g., LPS in gram-negative bacteria)
wrong.action: PAMPs are conserved features shared across pathogen groups

wrong.answer: PRRs are only found on phagocytes
wrong.fix: Many cell types express PRRs, including epithelial cells and dendritic cells
wrong.action: PRRs on many cells = widespread pathogen detection

persistent.action: PRRs (like TLRs) detect PAMPs (like LPS, flagellin, viral RNA) = innate recognition

rounds.title: Foundation
rounds.instructions: Learn the basic features and components of innate immunity.

tabSections.title: Innate Immunity Features
tabSections.instructions: Understand what makes innate immunity distinct from adaptive immunity.

sentences.text: Innate immunity is present from {{d1}} and provides {{d2}} defence against a wide range of pathogens.

d1.tooltip: When is innate immunity first available?

d2.tooltip: How quickly does innate immunity respond?

sentences.text: Unlike adaptive immunity, innate responses are {{d1}} and do not form immunological {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Does innate immunity target specific pathogens?

d2.tooltip: What does adaptive immunity form that innate doesn't?

sentences.text: Pattern recognition receptors detect conserved pathogen features called {{d1}}-associated molecular {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Where do these molecular patterns come from?

d2.tooltip: What are the conserved features called?

tabSections.title: Phagocytosis Basics
tabSections.instructions: Learn the process of pathogen engulfment and destruction.

sentences.text: Phagocytes engulf pathogens into membrane-bound vesicles called {{d1}}, which then fuse with {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What vesicle initially contains the engulfed pathogen?

d2.tooltip: What organelle provides digestive enzymes?

sentences.text: The combined vesicle called a {{d1}} contains enzymes and {{d2}} oxygen species that destroy pathogens.

d1.tooltip: What is the fused vesicle called?

d2.tooltip: What type of oxygen species kill pathogens?

sentences.text: Professional phagocytes include {{d1}}, macrophages, and {{d2}} cells.

d1.tooltip: Which granulocytes are the most common phagocytes?

d2.tooltip: Which antigen-presenting cells are also phagocytic?

tabSections.title: Complement System Basics
tabSections.instructions: Learn about the complement cascade and its functions.

sentences.text: The complement system consists of proteins that circulate in {{d1}} and are activated in a {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Where are complement proteins found?

d2.tooltip: How is complement activation organised?

sentences.text: Complement {{d1}} pathogens by coating them, making them easier for {{d2}} to recognise and engulf.

d1.tooltip: What is coating pathogens for phagocytosis called?

d2.tooltip: Which cells engulf opsonised pathogens?

sentences.text: The membrane attack complex (MAC) creates {{d1}} in pathogen membranes, causing {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What does MAC form in membranes?

d2.tooltip: What happens when cells have holes in their membranes?

sentences.text: Inflammation causes {{d1}}, which increases blood flow and makes vessels more {{d2}} to immune cells.

d1.tooltip: What vascular change increases blood flow?

d2.tooltip: What allows immune cells to exit blood vessels?

sentences.text: The cardinal signs of inflammation are redness, {{d1}}, swelling, {{d2}}, and loss of function.

d1.tooltip: What temperature change occurs at inflammation sites?

d2.tooltip: What sensation is caused by inflammatory mediators?

sentences.text: Fever is triggered by {{d1}} that signal the hypothalamus to raise the body's temperature {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What substances trigger fever?

d2.tooltip: What temperature reference does the hypothalamus control?

rounds.title: Application
rounds.instructions: Apply innate immunity concepts to understand immune mechanisms.

tabSections.title: Pattern Recognition
tabSections.instructions: Understand how the innate immune system detects pathogens.

sentences.text: Toll-like receptors (TLRs) are a family of {{d1}} that recognise specific pathogen {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What class of receptors are TLRs?

d2.tooltip: What do TLRs recognise on pathogens?

sentences.text: TLR4 recognises {{d1}}, a component of gram-{{d2}} bacterial cell walls.

d1.tooltip: What bacterial PAMP does TLR4 detect?

d2.tooltip: Which bacterial type has LPS?

sentences.text: PRR activation triggers signalling cascades that lead to {{d1}} production and {{d2}} activation.

d1.tooltip: What signalling molecules are produced after PRR activation?

d2.tooltip: What cells are activated by PRR signalling?

tabSections.title: Phagocyte Mechanisms
tabSections.instructions: Understand the details of phagocytic killing.

sentences.text: The respiratory burst produces {{d1}} oxygen species including superoxide and {{d2}} peroxide.

d1.tooltip: What type of oxygen species are toxic to pathogens?

d2.tooltip: Which peroxide is produced during respiratory burst?

sentences.text: Lysosomal enzymes include {{d1}}, which breaks down bacterial cell walls, and {{d2}} that digest proteins.

d1.tooltip: Which enzyme degrades peptidoglycan?

d2.tooltip: What enzymes break down proteins?

sentences.text: After killing, macrophages process antigens and present them on {{d1}} to activate {{d2}} immunity.

d1.tooltip: What molecules present external antigens?

d2.tooltip: What type of immunity is activated by antigen presentation?

tabSections.title: Cytokine Functions
tabSections.instructions: Understand how cytokines coordinate immune responses.

sentences.text: {{d1}} are cytokines that signal between leukocytes, while tumour necrosis factor promotes {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What cytokines communicate between white blood cells?

d2.tooltip: What does TNF promote?

sentences.text: {{d1}} are cytokines that attract immune cells to infection sites through {{d2}} gradients.

d1.tooltip: What cytokines guide cell movement?

d2.tooltip: What type of gradient do cells follow?

sentences.text: Type I interferons (α and β) induce an {{d1}} state in cells by upregulating genes that inhibit viral {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What protective state do Type I interferons induce?

d2.tooltip: What viral process is inhibited?

tabSections.title: Coordinated Responses
tabSections.instructions: Understand how systemic responses work together.

sentences.text: Mast cell {{d1}} releases histamine, which causes vasodilation and attracts {{d2}} to the site.

d1.tooltip: What is the release of mast cell granule contents called?

d2.tooltip: What cells are attracted to inflammation sites?

sentences.text: Elevated temperature during fever enhances {{d1}} activity and inhibits {{d2}} replication.

d1.tooltip: Whose activity is enhanced by fever?

d2.tooltip: Whose replication is inhibited by fever?

sentences.text: Complement fragment C5a is a potent {{d1}} that recruits neutrophils and promotes {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What does C5a do to immune cells?

d2.tooltip: What response does C5a promote?

rounds.title: Synthesis
rounds.instructions: Integrate innate immunity concepts with clinical and pathological contexts.

tabSections.title: Clinical Connections
tabSections.instructions: Apply innate immunity understanding to disease and treatment.

sentences.text: Sepsis occurs when the innate immune response becomes {{d1}}, causing systemic {{d2}} and organ failure.

d1.tooltip: What happens to the immune response in sepsis?

d2.tooltip: What spreads throughout the body in sepsis?

sentences.text: Immunodeficiencies affecting {{d1}} lead to recurrent bacterial infections that the body cannot {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Which cells are critical for bacterial defence?

d2.tooltip: What can't the body do to bacteria without phagocytes?

sentences.text: Anti-inflammatory drugs like NSAIDs reduce {{d1}} production, relieving pain and {{d2}} but potentially slowing healing.

d1.tooltip: What inflammatory mediators do NSAIDs block?

d2.tooltip: What symptom is reduced besides pain?

tabSections.title: Pathogen Evasion
tabSections.instructions: Understand how pathogens evade innate defences.

sentences.text: Some bacteria produce {{d1}} that destroy phagocytes, preventing {{d2}} and allowing infection to spread.

d1.tooltip: What bacterial products kill phagocytes?

d2.tooltip: What phagocyte function is prevented?

sentences.text: Capsules on bacteria prevent complement {{d1}} and {{d2}} recognition by phagocytes.

d1.tooltip: What can't complement do to capsulated bacteria?

d2.tooltip: What can't phagocytes recognise without complement?

sentences.text: Viruses like HIV can {{d1}} interferon signalling, allowing continued replication despite host {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What do some viruses do to interferon signalling?

d2.tooltip: What are viruses evading?

tabSections.title: Therapeutic Applications
tabSections.instructions: Apply innate immunity knowledge to treatments.

sentences.text: Recombinant interferons are used to treat {{d1}} infections and some cancers by boosting {{d2}} responses.

d1.tooltip: What infections are interferons used for?

d2.tooltip: What type of response do interferons boost?

sentences.text: Complement inhibitors are used in diseases where excessive complement causes {{d1}} damage to {{d2}} tissues.

d1.tooltip: What type of damage does excess complement cause?

d2.tooltip: Whose tissues are damaged by uncontrolled complement?

sentences.text: Adjuvants in vaccines contain TLR {{d1}} that activate innate immunity to enhance {{d2}} immune responses.

d1.tooltip: What do adjuvants contain that activate TLRs?

d2.tooltip: What immunity do vaccines aim to generate?

tabSections.title: Integration with Adaptive Immunity
tabSections.instructions: Understand how innate immunity connects to adaptive responses.

sentences.text: Dendritic cells provide the crucial link by processing antigens during innate responses and presenting them to activate {{d1}} {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Which lymphocytes do dendritic cells activate?

d2.tooltip: What are activated by antigen presentation?

sentences.text: Cytokines produced during innate responses determine the {{d1}} of adaptive immunity, directing helper T cell {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: What aspect of adaptive immunity do cytokines influence?

d2.tooltip: What process do cytokines direct in T cells?

sentences.text: Complement-coated antigens are more efficiently taken up by B cells, enhancing {{d1}} production and {{d2}} formation.

d1.tooltip: What do activated B cells produce?

d2.tooltip: What long-lasting cells are formed?
